content: Ok so I just got back from vacation and picked my cat up from the vet where I boarded her while I was away. Perfectly normal event right? Here is the issue. The vet is a long time friend, actually a relative(second cousin) and he informed me he could no longer board Smokey. He did give me a reason fortunately. It seems she became very aggitated and violent towards him and his employees. I understand that if that is the case he should not keep her. Now when I walked in to pick her up she came right to me, climbed into my arms, and purred as we went home. Having talked with the vet, and knowing him for so long I trust him without any doubt as to how he says the cat reacted. But he also was somewhat shocked at the cats change of behavior when I walked in compared to how she acted over the time she was there and says he has never seen such behavioral changes in any cat. I want to know if anyone else has had such an experience and what might cause it. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.
title: Question on feline behavior

content: I had a cat several years ago, it liked some people and didn't like others. I don't think your cat's behavior is unusual, and it was probably missing you as well.
reply: I had a cat several years ago, it liked some people and didn't like others. I don't think your cat's behavior is unusual, and it was probably missing you as well.
title: Question on feline behavior

content: Cat's are unique, they determine whom they like and don't like. They can be very independent, there is a saying. "When you call a dog, it comes to you". "When you call a cat, it say's leave a message, I'll get back to you!" Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
reply: Cat's are unique, they determine whom they like and don't like. They can be very independent, there is a saying. "When you call a dog, it comes to you". "When you call a cat, it say's leave a message, I'll get back to you!" Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!
title: Question on feline behavior

content: I have 4 cats, 3 of them are old timers 9 years old. The 4th one is young about a year old. They just don't change their moods over night. Something was in the vets office to make your cat act that way. We plan a trip to CA in a couple of months and we plan on having someone come over and feed our cats. I have 2 big liter boxes that I have in our bathrooms. One cat stays outside, she is on the wild side, but she has a little house in the backyard that the 4 dogs don't bother. I want to keep them in the house the whole time cause we have coyotes and I don't want to lose anymore cats. I think your cat will be happier if she was allowed to stay home while you were gone, unless you were gone for a long long long time. We will be gone for about a week. The friend that will feed ours is a good friend and he will also clean the liter boxes too. If you were close to me I would do the same for you just because I love cats, actually I love all animals.

title: Question on feline behavior

content: try another kennel, but don't go "cold turkey" for the entire vacation. Start out with an overnite stay and a pick up the next morning. do this a once or twice and the cat'll get the message that you ARE coming back, and it's not the fault of the kennel people for making you go away. I'd also work on introducing the acutual handlers to your cat once or twice BEFORE leaving the cat. have treats etc. available and get the handler's scent on toys that you bring back home. Most kennels will do this.
reply: try another kennel, but don't go "cold turkey" for the entire vacation. Start out with an overnite stay and a pick up the next morning. do this a once or twice and the cat'll get the message that you ARE coming back, and it's not the fault of the kennel people for making you go away. I'd also work on introducing the acutual handlers to your cat once or twice BEFORE leaving the cat. have treats etc. available and get the handler's scent on toys that you bring back home. Most kennels will do this.
title: Question on feline behavior

content: quote: Originally posted by Bergy46: Cat's are unique, they determine whom they like and don't like. They can be very independent, there is a saying. "When you call a dog, it comes to you". "When you call a cat, it say's leave a message, I'll get back to you!" That's so true, Bergy! We have five moggies (and three dogs). One of our moggies (Brit English for "cats") actively avoids me, while shmoosing up to my wife at every possible opportunity. There's no logical explanation for her behaviour, since I've always treated all of them equally from when we got them (all sisters from one litter). There's an obvious "hacking order" among them and I have to be careful to comply with that when I greet them. But it always amazes me when "Snoggy" (the moggy in question) turns up for a cuddle and a stroke (she's sort of "third" in line), only to slope off and ignore me completely afterwards. It's one of the reasons why I absolutely love moggies! They're so uncompromising in their likes and dislikes. We (humans) could actually learn a lot from them. MsG

There's an obvious "hacking order" among them and I have to be careful to comply with that when I greet them. title: Question on feline behavior

content: My daughter had a cat. She took it when she moved out. It never much cared for me outright but wouldn't hiss at me either. She moved in with a girlfriend that had two small kids that would always want to play with the kitty. torture to the cat but the kiddies didn't understand. After some time I was asked to retrieve the cat and bring it back home. I went to the apartment and was told the cat was behind the couch and wouldn't come out. We pulled the couch out about a foot on one end and I looked at the cat, called her name, and to my surprise she came right to me. She purred in my arms all the way home and has come to me every time that I have called her since. That was 2 years ago. She even let's me scratch under her neck by extending her head up in the air. Cat's DO NOT expose their necks unless that trust is explicit. Weird but true...

title: Question on feline behavior

content: Well, I've got a question that may sound pretty stupid to cat owners. The wife got a cat about a year ago, and I swear I've never had ANYTHING to do with this cat.(I'm a dog guy) The wife, older kids pet it , the Grandkids play with it constantly when they are here. I NEVER touched this cat ........ Until-- about a month ago, when it jumped into MY chair as I was watching a ballgame and now I can't get away from the thing. If you can answer this, it'd sure save me from looking over to the wife and saying "What the hell is this all about?"
reply: Well, I've got a question that may sound pretty stupid to cat owners. The wife got a cat about a year ago, and I swear I've never had ANYTHING to do with this cat.(I'm a dog guy) The wife, older kids pet it , the Grandkids play with it constantly when they are here. I NEVER touched this cat ........ Until-- about a month ago, when it jumped into MY chair as I was watching a ballgame and now I can't get away from the thing. If you can answer this, it'd sure save me from looking over to the wife and saying "What the hell is this all about?"
title: Question on feline behavior

content: JustanotherGI, you sound like my father. He is a dog person, but if there is a game on, and he is in his chair, the cats "claim" him in no time at all. Cats tend to know who they can and cannot trust. The cat has looked you over and found you to be acceptable, or atleast acceptable when you are in your chair. The other possibility is the cat thinks that is its' chair and is just using you for extra padding. Everyone else, thanks for the ideas, but the cat has been there before usually for one or two days at the time, like when she was fixed, or if I was out of twon for the weekend, and no problems, I'd just never seen a cat take such umbrage with the vet before. As to using another boarding facility, not possible, my town is a few thousand people on a good day, we got one vet is all, so you can see the issue there. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

content: It may be there was another animal boarded nearby that distressed your cat. Throw that possibility out to your vet and try see if he's open to trying again.
reply: It may be there was another animal boarded nearby that distressed your cat. Throw that possibility out to your vet and try see if he's open to trying again.
title: Question on feline behavior

content: quote: Originally posted by JustanotherGI: Well, I've got a question that may sound pretty stupid to cat owners. The wife got a cat about a year ago, and I swear I've never had ANYTHING to do with this cat.(I'm a dog guy) The wife, older kids pet it , the Grandkids play with it constantly when they are here. I NEVER touched this cat ........ Until-- about a month ago, when it jumped into MY chair as I was watching a ballgame and now I can't get away from the thing. If you can answer this, it'd sure save me from looking over to the wife and saying "What the hell is this all about?" Cats have a totally different mindset than dogs. They reevaluate their relationship with those around them all the time. Your cat decided that you passed muster and for the time being anyway he's made you his pet. Perhaps your stand off attitude was helpful. I know a lot of guys don't like cats but that's mainly because one can never mold a cat into what one wants it to be. Dogs, on the other hand are the exact opposite. Feed them and show them some affection and they're yours for life. How come I pressed "One for English" and still can't understand a word the dude is saying?

title: Question on feline behavior

content: Wasn't due to another animal, we discussed that. The cat just dislikes the vet and his people. When they were not in the room with the animal, she was fine, one of them came in sight and she went nuts. Being a relative has benefiets, we dropped by today after church to see if she was alright. If he got within 15 feet of her she freaked, if he backed off a hair she mellowed out again. He says he has never seen anything like it. Neither of us can make sense of it. Smokey seems to have very strong likes and dislikes, and people she doesn't hang out with alot are appearantly a major dislike. Bergy, very true, you don't own a cat, the cat owns you. “If you bring these leaders to trial, it will condemn the North, for by the Constitution, secession is not rebellion...His (Jeff Davis') capture was a mistake. His trial will be a greater one. We cannot convict him of treason." Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase, 1867.

title: Question on feline behavior

content: I have worked at numerous boarding kennels and feel bad in situations like the one you are going through. Trust me; when a decision is made to tell a client that a pet will not be allowed to board again, it is for the best. Was your cat injured, or was a staff member injured by your cat? With dogs, there's the destruction of property reason too, but I don't think that one applies to your kitty. Reasons for this occuring could be as simple as your calming and familiar voice was no longer there to make sense of it all for your cat. And then there are the obvious things like different sights, sounds, and smells. Noisy, echoing cages, strange/weird people, barking dogs, hissing cats, litterbox odors, attempts to catch the cat (if it tries to escape),and lack of routine happenings. I've also seen one instance where the staff wasn't very cat-friendly, so the decision was made to tell the client no more boarding their cat. I hope that's not the case for you, but even if it was, take note. The cause WILL present itself again if you board your cat there, and your cat doesn't need that. Sounds like a pet sitter is your best bet next time around
reply: I have worked at numerous boarding kennels and feel bad in situations like the one you are going through. Trust me; when a decision is made to tell a client that a pet will not be allowed to board again, it is for the best. Was your cat injured, or was a staff member injured by your cat? With dogs, there's the destruction of property reason too, but I don't think that one applies to your kitty. Reasons for this occuring could be as simple as your calming and familiar voice was no longer there to make sense of it all for your cat. And then there are the obvious things like different sights, sounds, and smells. Noisy, echoing cages, strange/weird people, barking dogs, hissing cats, litterbox odors, attempts to catch the cat (if it tries to escape),and lack of routine happenings. I've also seen one instance where the staff wasn't very cat-friendly, so the decision was made to tell the client no more boarding their cat. I hope that's not the case for you, but even if it was, take note. The cause WILL present itself again if you board your cat there, and your cat doesn't need that. Sounds like a pet sitter is your best bet next time around
